channel.title: Math equation help?
channel.description:
Does anyone know the answer to this problem?
5!-10=x ?

item.title: Math equation help?
item.dc:creator: @vManlyMan vManlyMan
item.description:
@vManlyMan wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:12, topic:440473”][quote author=vManlyMan link=topic=543156.msg3981686#msg3981686 date=1335354783]

X is exposed to be the answer you have to find, it not really x=# its just a variable.

Of course! This makes so much sense! How could we not grasp this concept? That X is exposed to be the answer that we find and it’s not a number! It’s just a variable! I expose we must just been not thinking straight at the moment.

I think he just made these topics for postcount. Not because he actually needs help.
[/quote]
Why do you think that?
Post–count is worthless anyway.[/quote]

He made 7, completely pointless topics in one day. And from reading through this topic, it doesn’t seem like he knows anything about what he’s asking, which makes me believe he’s not actually studying this.

Read full topic

item.title: Math equation help?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:8, topic:440473”]Here’s a really common use:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_coefficient[/quote]

They still only use two factorials, and nothing else :P.

I guess I’m just nitpicking.

Read full topic

item.title: Math equation help?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:7, topic:440473”][quote author=t4 link=topic=543156.msg3981128#msg3981128 date=1335283212]

It’s been a while since I did anything with factorials, but isn’t this an odd equation? Why would you subtract 10 from 5!? Or better yet, why would you want to solve for x? Learning factorials can be done by an equation such as 5!-3!=x.

5 factorial minus 10, what’s wrong with that?
[/quote]

There’s nothing wrong with it, it’s a perfectly valid equation. What I mean is that, at least to me, there is no real point in subtracting any number from a factorial. Bear in mind, Maths was only a minor subject in my education. We only used, and I know we doesn’t really cover the entire mathematical world, but we only used factorials in probability calculations. So 5! would be the odds of 5 sequential events, which exclude itself after that event took place. Like picking teammates for a game of dodgeball. Once someone is picked, you can’t pick him again.

In that case, there is no point in subtracting any number from a factorial. Or is there? I know the point is to teach factorials, but still.[/quote]
Most factorials I’ve found surface in discrete mathematics, probability or sequences/series and most of the time they’re in a fractional form where terms will quickly cancel. I don’t recall ever adding a constant to a factorial, however.

Here’s a really common use:

en.wikipedia.org

Binomial coefficient

In mathematics, any of the positive integers that occurs as a coefficient in the binomial theorem is a binomial coefficient. Commonly, a binomial coefficient is indexed by a pair of integers n ≥ k ≥ 0 and is written ( n k ) . {\displaystyle ...

Read full topic

item.title: Math equation help?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:6, topic:440473”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=543156.msg3981108#msg3981108 date=1335281072]
It’s been a while since I did anything with factorials, but isn’t this an odd equation? Why would you subtract 10 from 5!? Or better yet, why would you want to solve for x? Learning factorials can be done by an equation such as 5!-3!=x.
[/quote]
5 factorial minus 10, what’s wrong with that?[/quote]

There’s nothing wrong with it, it’s a perfectly valid equation. What I mean is that, at least to me, there is no real point in subtracting any number from a factorial. Bear in mind, Maths was only a minor subject in my education. We only used, and I know we doesn’t really cover the entire mathematical world, but we only used factorials in probability calculations. So 5! would be the odds of 5 sequential events, which exclude itself after that event took place. Like picking teammates for a game of dodgeball. Once someone is picked, you can’t pick him again.

In that case, there is no point in subtracting any number from a factorial. Or is there? I know the point is to teach factorials, but still.

Read full topic

item.title: Math equation help?
item.dc:creator: @RDG RDG
item.description:
@RDG wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:2, topic:440473”]N! stand for N factorial. Factorial is defined as: (N) (N-1) (N-2) … (N-N).

In this case:
[(5)(5-1)(5-2)(5-3)(5-4)(5-5)] - 10 = x

note: both 1 and 0 factorial are 1.[/quote]

Oh ok Thanks :D.

Read full topic

item.title: Math equation help?
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

N! stand for N factorial. Factorial is defined as: (N) (N-1) (N-2) … (N-N).

In this case:
[(5)(5-1)(5-2)(5-3)(5-4)(5-5)] - 10 = x

note: both 1 and 0 factorial are 1.

Read full topic
